awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Novel Relaxations for Cardinality-constrained  Optimization Problems with Applications in Network Interdiction and Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In many fields, such as telecommunication, logistics, and genetics, a decision-maker often prefers to find a solution, where only a fraction of potential resource assignments is selected. Such solutions are easier to interpret and implement, but they may be difficult to identify. Leveraging new structural results, the investigators develop new techniques to obtain high quality solutions to these types of problems. This project will apply these techniques to data analysis and network interdiction problems.  Network interdiction models have been successfully used to identify vulnerabilities in power and water systems, and to secure networked systems. Improved methods will help create better predictive models and yield tools to enhance national security. This research will also support training of graduate and undergraduate students and creation of pedagogical material.

This project seeks to develop new convex relaxation techniques that will lead to stronger relaxation bounds for cardinality constrained mathematical programs (CCMPs) and improve the convergence of generic and custom branch-and-bound codes for mixed integer nonlinear programs. Specifically, the researchers will (i) investigate bilinear formulations of cardinality requirements through the lens of the recently developed convexification procedures; (ii) focus on disjunctive relaxations previously introduced for linear relaxations of CCMPs, which can be used to generate cuts from any simplex basic solution that does not satisfy a cardinality constraint; (iii) develop cutting plane strategies that can generate convex hull descriptions devised from extensions of reformulation-linearization techniques; and (iv) utilize the concept of permutation-invariance to develop new formulations and relaxations for CCMPs arising in data analysis and models of various logical propositions. The project will also investigate the application of these results to the KKT formulation of network interdiction with asymmetric information.  The investigators will also make use of these improved relaxations in the development of heuristic and exact solution techniques for sparse principal component analysis.

Accomplishments:

In many applications, decision-makers will prefer solutions where only a fraction of potential resource assignments is selected. These considerations give rise to cardinality-constrained mathematical programs (CCMPs).  We derived the following new relaxation and formulation techniques that improve the efficiency of MINLP techniques for CCMPs.

  • Tree ensemble optimization (TEO) is the problem of optimizing a function whose value is predicted by a tree ensemble. We established that TEO and the optimization of multilinear functions over the Cartesian product of simplices are polynomially equivalent. This insight allowed us to transfer results between problems.  It permitted the development of stronger formulations for TEO from considerations on the associated multilinear sets.  It also allowed us to introduce new convex hull results for multilinear polytopes from insights on TEO.  The new formulations demonstrated significant computational gains on multicommodity transportation problems with tree-ensemble objectives. This work also led us to introduce a new variant of decision trees with better out-of-sample fit for continuous nonlinear functions.
  • Multilinear functions are crucial in the solution of factorable optimization problems. One approach to relax multilinear functions over a domain is to suitably approximate them with piecewise polyhedral relaxations. We developed improved relaxations for multilinear optimization problems over axis-parallel regular hyper-rectangular partitions. The relaxations we propose introduce linking constraints that connect relaxations of various multilinear terms with one another. When added to ALPINE, an open-source global software, linking constraints yield significant computational improvements on polynomial and multilinear instances. For non-regular hyperrectangles, we produced the first ideal MILP formulations. Although rarely studied, we demonstrate that such formulations are needed as they can be exponentially more efficient at modeling certain functions than regular partitions. When used to model certain linear decision trees compactly, we demonstrate numerically that these formulations have much better performance.
  • We developed various heuristics for TEO that proceed by producing smaller TEO instances that are readily solved. We found that it is often more effective to directly use the data that generated the ensemble than using the tree ensemble itself. In particular, the problem of finding a good feasible solution for TEO can be expressed as that of finding a collection of sufficiently close data points with maximum average value. This is an integer program whose solution is readily obtained using constraint generation and provides high quality solutions.
  • Permutation-invariance is a property of sets that requires that a feasible solution vector remains feasible after any permutation of its components. We developed structural results that reduce the convexification of permutation-invariant sets to the convexification of much simpler sets.  This fundamental result as many important applications. First, it permits the convexification of cardinality-constrained feasible solutions of the unit ball. This result, in turn, permits the creation of strong formulations for Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA). This formulation serves as the basis for yet another formulation for SPCA that uses additional binary variables and closes almost all the gap remaining in the classical SDP relaxation. The fundamental result can also be used to describe convex hulls of matrices satisfying certain requirements on their eigenvalues and to construct convex hull descriptions of permutation-invariant nonlinear functions over special hypercubes.  When applied to sets where all variables are binary, our fundamental result allows the convexification of sets in variables x and y such that the cardinality of vector y belongs to L whenever the cardinality of x belongs to K.  Since the construction applies to an arbitrary number of vectors x and y, it subsumes all special cases described in the literature, including forbidden inequalities. To tackle the case where variables x overlap in multiple conditions, we introduce a decomposition result that still permits the construction of convex hulls. Along the way, we develop convex hull formulations of the cardinality indicating and sum indicating polytopes of integer variables and develop new techniques to relax propositional formulas that connect various permutation-invariant sets. 

 

Outcomes:

This grant supported fundamental work to derive improved formulations for CCMPs.  The techniques we introduced for permutation-invariant sets yield new avenues for generating formulations for models that are central to global optimization. The formulations and heuristics we introduced for TEO suggest that there are practical ways to solve optimization models directly from data, even when functional representations of constraints/objectives are not directly accessible. The connection we made between TEO and multilinear optimization yields new computational ways to handle nonconvex problems. This work also shed light on the fact that TEO can improve our ability to solve problems to global optimality. Indeed, inking constraints have already been integrated into ALPINE source code.

Many problems in data analysis can be expressed as CCMPs, for which our work provides new techniques. Descriptive models, such as random forest, have gained common acceptance. With this grant, we provided fundamental results to enable their transition into prescriptive tools, which would benefit practitioners in a variety of fields.
